I do not have to work on the floor beyond passing meds so I feel safer, but I am still exposed to the sounds and drama of the unit.
cons: There needs to be more staff on Swing and Weekend shifts. Some of the clients are very dangerous and aggressive. I have seen clients and staff hurt badly. People who do not work in the units with the clients should not be making decisions lightly. They need to trust the experience and wisdom of the Supervisors who are on the floor so that everyone can be safe.

review_title: Learned many clinical skills, terrible management

review_title: High stress, low pay, strong work experience

You will learn strong collaborative problem solving skills, how to react in high stress situations, how to de-escalate clients using DBT, CBT, distraction, and effective communication. 

Your experience here will be impressive to future employers who value such experience.
cons:
The high stress environment and almost daily involvement in holds may be traumatizing. 

The pay is very poor, although it's probably representative for a bachelor's level and below mental health position.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Portland, OR
pros: Coworkers and management are great.  My immediate supervisors have been supportive, knowledgeable, and advocate for a healthy work/life balance.  Upper management seems to follow through on improvements needed and noted by staff.  The company works hard to do the best it can do for children and families who are experiencing significant mental health issues.
cons:
The Electronic Health Records software has been problematic for a long time (clunky interface, inefficient layout, lock-ups/crashes often) but it sounds like vendor will be brought in within a year to get a new EHR system up and running.
I have experienced several instances where I feel like I received poor training especially from supervisors or from staff whose sole job is to train staff.  Not sure where the breakdown occurs, but this has been a rather problem.
The pay rate is not great and raises appear hard to come by.
The company has a low amount of full time non-residential non-administrative non-management jobs.  It's the nature of what the company does (primarily residential programs).

job_title: Health Services Consultant in Portland, OR
pros:
Supporting children

job_title: Child and Family Therapist in Portland, OR
pros:
Staff really care about the clients, at least on my team.

Lots of flexibility as to what works for clients within the therapeutic context.  Non-rigid in therapeutic approach.
cons: Billing system is productivity fee for service based. Trillium foots the bill when productivity is not met (rather than the schools we work in).  This instills pressure from the top down, which results in the therapists feeling the heat of needing to raise productivity and generate income for the agency.  It feels pretty bad.  As a result, turnover on my team is very high; it seems people are leaving every month.

pros: co workers and the kids create a trauma bond
cons: Management like to have sexual intercourse with their subordinates

pros: The kids are great to work with. Generally people who work here are not looking to get rich, they are looking to make a difference in the lives of children and adolescents. Trillium has a wonderful trauma informed culture with great values. It has an atmosphere of hope and healing and is working hard on becoming sanctuary certified. Trillium family services is doing a great job practicing the latest evidence-based treatments and philosophies of care. I've never had such good supervisors at any other job. The staff here a special set of people.
cons: If you are a recent graduate you will not be able to afford to survive on the pay they offer you as a skills trainer. You will not be able to make rent, student loan payments and afford to feed and clothe yourself. You cannot support a family on this wage. If you have 1 child the pay is not a living wage and you will be below the poverty line and will qualify for welfare benefits. The required annual income for survival for just 1 adult and 1 child in Benton County is $39,848. Many staff get badly injured from working here and they need to be getting paid more for the sacrifice.

review_title: Working in mental health can be detrimental to your mental health at TFS
pros: I had a wonderful boss/ manager - she was very empathetic, open-minded, professional and friendly, rocked at her job, and then she was laid off. Her position was vital to new hires yet she was let go due to cutbacks (non-profit issues). She should have been retained and people who didn't do their jobs should have been laid off instead.
cons:
- Too many people were "fake" - nice to your face, but talked behind other people's backs
- The mental health of employees was not treated as a top priority
- Upper management was shady
- "too many chiefs, not enough Indians"
- Higher ups were not always held accountable 
- lack of prioritization in training
-experienced employees getting fired after being injured on the job
- safety issues not addressed in a timely manner

pros:
Trillium Family Services truly has a remarkable, positive work environment.  We follow the "Sanctuary" Model which promotes safety and recovery from adversity through the active creation of a trauma-informed community.   

I have a background in administrative work in large corporations, as well as having been a special education teacher in juvenile detention.  Non-profit organizations may not be the highest-paying, but you cannot put a dollar amount on a career where you feel good about going to work every day, knowing that you are helping kids, and work in an environment that provides/promotes safety for clients and staff.  We have a saying around here, "Instead of asking someone what is wrong with them...ask what happened to them."

I love Trillium and truly believe that this will be the last job I will have until retirement!
cons: Never enough funds to do all of the projects with the kids that you we would like!

job_title: Child and Family Therapist in Corvallis, OR
pros:
Great entry level salary and benefits, paid licensing supervision, and some flexibility to work from home.  When you leave, you will feel like you can handle anything.
They have great values but the intensity of the position often made it difficult to engage in the values.
cons: Highly challenging population to service with minimal emotional support available for staff.  Heavy focus on productivity with questionable ethics regarding billing as a means to meet this demand.  Constantly expected to meet a high productivity rate even though I had no control of whether or not my clients showed.  They are already VERY difficult to help and the added pressure from upper management that is filtered through our overworked direct supervisors felt insulting.

pros: You get to help kids at their lowest points, help keep things safe, and be a mentor and advocate for those who need it.
cons: Chronic understaffing. Especially in Powers and Sequoia (SAIP units) you are under critical staffing and there is insufficient walkie talkies. You will often work up to 12 hours (swing shift) without being able to take breaks or eat at times. You are exposed to a lot of secondhand and firsthand trauma and a lot of employees are not well trained and end up in the ER. Make sure you are equipped to handle high stress and dangerous situations while the staff is facing emotional and mental burnout.

review_title: With Great Freedom Comes Great Responsibility
pros: I loved the freedom to create the Prevention Program the way I wanted to.  It was a wonderful way to try out new curriculum, develop therapeutic groups to meet current client needs, etc.  Working in schools was great and there was a nice partnership between the agency and the school.
cons: I did not feel supported as an employee.  Clinical supervision was lacking and due to the nature of the position I was the only mental health professional in the school regularly. The caseloads were high and very intensive in needs. Lots of crisis intervention work, which was good practice but bad for burnout.

review_title: Can be great experience at a high risk
pros: Amazing co-workers. Easy to build friendships. Good healthcare coverage. Free meals. They try to be supportive of staff’s mental health if you need a day off. Decent pay for entry level position. Real experience to support and advocate for clients while collaborating with therapist, nurses, and psychiatrist. Very inclusive/friendly for LGBTQA and trans issues for clients and staff. Strong training on crisis intervention and how to do holds in a safe way that is trauma informed/really tries to prevent anyone from getting hurt in the process.
cons: Physical and emotional risk. You will likely get physically hurt at some point or you will see it happen to a co-worker.  High level of emotional abuse from clients, especially in older units. Sometimes being expected to work overtime due to crisis or short staffing. Being expected to use your own phone on the job and not getting reimbursed if it breaks. Clients being placed in the wrong unit due to a bad intake, and then staff having to work with a client that they don’t know how to fully support/runs a higher risk of others getting hurt until that client is discharged to another unit on campus, or full on hospital care. Some clients will trigger other clients which can be challenging to deal with in a residential space. You’ll see parents who have awful parenting skills and continue to negatively support a clients mental health which makes treatment take longer.  Not a lot of ways to move up in the organization unless you want to become a supervisor or work part time while getting your masters in social work/counseling.

review_title: Clients Falsely Imprisoned For Psychiatric Hope?
pros: You're in a position of power over troubled youth who are being taken advantage of by this firm.
cons: They will whine about how they're here against their will and how they haven't seen their parents for a while. We collect $50,000 a month in insurance funds to treat them under the guise of psychiatric illness. The truth is none of these kids are mentally deranged. Well, a few of them are but most are trouble makers and kids who ran away from home.

pros: Nice place, they work at the whole "trauma informed care" thing at a managerial level.

job_title: Outpatient Child and Family Therapist in Corvallis, OR
pros: The pay is alright and the hours are okay.
cons: I started working here with high-hopes. The downside was the reality of the situation. My boss made me fill out the forums on clientele in a negative light to keep them there longer for insurance money. We were forced to infer mainly negative things. When I spoke up about this in a board meeting I was fired. The place is ran as a detention facility that rakes in profit. Most of the kids don't deserve to be here nor accept the treatment they receive. If people really knew what this place was doing it wouldn't exist.
